Hi Jeff, 

well it is both :) When I made my ID card they asked me how do I=
 want 
my name spelled in latin and chose this one.. :) 

I did that experi=
ment but it couldn't walk because it was falling all 
the time.. But some i=
ndividuals appeared that were actually crawling. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoo=
groups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Petar (or is it Peter?)-
=
> 
> That is an ambitious project, and I look forward to seeing it 
progres=
s.
> 
> One quick question: you mention below that you changed two things 
=
between
> the code you released and your 100% gait-producing setup. You 
sw=
itched to
> zero-G and you switched to looking for oscillations. Do I have =
that 
right?
> 
> Out of curiosity, did you try just searching for oscillat=
ions but 
not
> switching to zero-G? Alternately, did you try taking some o=
f your 
walkers
> from zero-G and then turning gravity on?
> 
> This raises=
 an interesting question in novelty search research: how 
can you
> use a g=
ood seed organism to kick-start a process? If you have a 
walker that
> mov=
es a few steps away and then falls, it seems that the beginning 
of
> novel=
ty search will simply reward the easy discovery of all the 
points
> around=
 center. So, instead of working on the walker's genome and 
moving
> farthe=
r out, it will revert to producing all the 'fall left', 'fall 
right',
> et=
c since that is the low hanging fruit. Once all that low hanging 
fruit is
=
> gone, the genome of the walker is probably lost. There would be a 
chance=
 of
> recovering it, I guess, if you periodically resurrected archive 
indi=
viduals
> when the population is stagnating. It may even be interesting to =

try to
> resurrect those individuals whose end-point is furthest from thos=
e 
points
> currently being visited by the population.
> 
> Just thinking o=
ut loud...
> 
> Very cool stuff. I'd love to see the zero-G guys if you can=
 post em!
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Mi=
chigan State University
> 
> jclune@...
> 
> 
> 
> 
> > From: petar_cherven=
ski <petar_chervenski@...>
> > Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoo=
groups.com>

> > To: "neat@yahoogr=
oups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> > Subject: [neat] Re: New file uploaded =
to neat
> > 
> > Hi Jeff, 
> > 
> > I am glad that you like my program and =
enjoy it! :)
> > 
> > I know it would be cool to browse the archive, or hav=
e an external
> > routine that queries the archive by different criteria to=
 show me
> > what was achieved during the run, but this program now is 
act=
ually a
> > stepping stone for another research project I have, evolving 
l=
eaky-
> > integrator substrates by HyperNEAT combined with evolving the
> >=
 substrate itself, all used in one Alife simulation of mass-spring
> > crea=
tures, sensing collision and reacting by contracting the 
springs.
> > And =
all this with Novelty Search searching for new and new 
behaviors.
> > I be=
lieve that this is a pretty serious test of how far complexity
> > can go i=
n such open-ended domain. I can later mix it with fitness
> > search once a=
 good population has evolved, on objectives
> > like "swimming". 
> > 
> > =
Let me mention about one interesting experiment I made with the NS
> > NEVH=
. I restricted the substrate connectivity so that output-
>output
> > conne=
ctions are not queried. Then I made the environment to 0 
gravity
> > and r=
emoved the ground plane. The behavior characterization was
> > changed like=
 this. The behavior data is a vector of 15 doubles
> > representing the out=
puts. Each time an output oscillates (going to
> > +treshold and then -tres=
hold, or vice versa), its corresponding 
place
> > in the vector is increme=
nted.
> > So the vector is actually counting how many oscillations the 
out=
puts
> > did during the lifetime. A substrate oscillating with high 
freque=
ncy
> > is very far in the behavior space. Different outputs oscillating 
a=
re
> > counted too. The behavior distance metric is the eucledian 
distance=

> > between these 15-D vectors.
> > 
> > So novelty search now has to find=
 new ways to oscillate the entire
> > body, to do repeating movements. In a=
ll the runs, Novelty Search 
with
> > HyperNEAT finds walking gaits 100% of=
 the time, in the first 1000
> > evaluations. There are also swimming gaits=
 and all kind of stuff 
(I
> > saw one individual actually dancing :))
> > =

> > So what was stopping it from walking before, is the gravity. 
Keeping
=
> > balance on one leg and trying to walk at the same time turns out 
to
> =
> be very hard task. One environmental constraint that would be 
useful
> >=
 to make it walk is, when only one foot has stepped on the ground,
> > stic=
k that foot to the ground. So the chance the humanoid to fall 
is
> > minim=
ized. 
> > 
> > As for the novelty search stagnation, where getting new beh=
aviors
> > becomes hard, the population begins to do something like a rando=
m
> > probing anything that is not the same stuff. Then it begins to 
rely
=
> > entirely on mutation to get out somehow.
> > 
> > Peter
> > 
> > --- In=
 neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> I finally bor=
rowed a windows machine from someone and looked at
> > this. It's
> >> real=
ly fun to watch! I am leaving it running overnight to see 
what
> > happens=
.
> >> So far the best I have seen has been about a five mini-step 
shuffle=

> >> backwards...although I have seen a few three mini-step forward
> > sh=
uffles.
> >> 
> >> Can you post either the genome and or a movie of the bes=
t org
> > you've seen so
> >> far? 
> >> 
> >> I second the notion that it =
would be cool to browse the archive,
> > especially
> >> if you could choos=
e archive members to view based on max distance
> > from 0,0
> >> or someth=
ing like that.
> >> 
> >> It might help you to visualize things if you adde=
d another 
viewing
> > mode that
> >> put a dot in the 3D viewer for every =
x,y,z coordinate in the
> > archive (one
> >> color) and in the current pop=
ulation (another color).
> >> 
> >> Watching this also makes me wonder abou=
t the population losing 
its
> > gradient
> >> and disengaging. Here is the=
 potential concern (and I think 
mattias
> > and ken
> >> discussed this al=
ready): Once all the easy to access points are
> > found, if
> >> most of t=
he orgs are not getting somewhere new, they will all 
have
> > equal
> >> f=
itnesses and the search will not be focused on the outside edge.
> > Do you=

> >> think this is happening (and might this be why David mentioned 
that
=
> > he saw a
> >> lot of repeats toward the end)? The visualization I just =
proposed
> > might help
> >> on this front. Do the points added in the arch=
ive tend to be
> > further and
> >> further away from 0,0....or is it just =
filling in the spaces in 
the
> > nearby
> >> vicinity? 
> >> 
> >> Despite=
 these concerns/suggestions, it is very fun stuff to look
> > at...and
> >>=
 its exciting that you are hybridizing these ideas so quickly and
> > testi=
ng
> >> them. 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff Clune
> >> 
> >> Digital =
Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
